utterances: The benefits of our work so far around things like reproductive rights aren't conferred equally across all women, and that's what I think particularly this younger generation of feminists and particularly feminists of color are sort of trying to wake us up to.
That's enlightened self-interest, says Boston University's Ashley Farmer.
When you make something that accounts for the most depressed, everybody's life tends to get better.
And maybe there has to be some upheaval before that happens.
UCLA's Grace Hong says the discord around today's marches is a good thing for feminism.
Maybe the point is to not all agree, you know, maybe the point is to do these kinds of things so that you can have the tough conversations.
(As character) Tell us.
Well, one of the things that the marshes used to be able to do was to support the unique lifestyle of the marsh Arabs.
Have they been able to return to their lives?
Indeed, 70,000 people have been documented to have come back to the perimeters of the marshes.
Two small communities that I know of that have basically come back actually to the middle of the marshes, to the water world of Settiger's(ph) fame.
And in one area, documenting--I have documents from the Upper Slobat(ph) area that basically shows there was only one family back in January of 2004.
Today we have 150 families.
The number of water buffalo in that area increased from five heads in January of 2004 to 6,000 today.
That's a story that tells you basically that people want to come back even though the services are still primitive.
I am actually afraid of more people coming back, to be honest with you, Neal.
At this point in time, they are, in my opinion, overstressing the recovering system.
As you know, fishing provides their major source of income.
The fishermen in the marshes today generate about 20,000 to 30,000 Iraqi dinars.
That's the equivalent of about 15 to $20 a day.
That's an incredible amount in Iraq.
That can feed a family of 10, say, for two or three days.
Anyway, so a lot of people are coming back to fish off of--you know, or to use fishing as their way of life.

And they're using electrocution, and in some cases, unfortunately, they're using poisoning to collect as much fish as possible to basically enhance their way of life or to create income for themselves.
So if more people come back today, I'm afraid that the environment is not in a sustainable condition as of yet.
We need to work a little bit more to kind of make sure that there's enough water that's coming back to the inundated areas, to even increase the amount of inundated areas.
Our research is indicating that though the water resources exist, they are limited.
We actually, by introducing some modern management techniques for the water, we can get a lot more than what is inundated today.
Though there are some obstacles on the way, more engineering than political or scientific, we're working through that.

We are trying to come up with a master plan in association with the three major ministries involved in this work in Iraq, the Ministry of Water Resources, the Ministry of Municipalities and Public Works and the Ministry of Environment.
We're trying to come up with a master plan for the restoration of the marshes itself as well as the restoration of the infrastructure of the cities and communities around the marshes.
You started your question about the marsh Arabs coming back.
They are coming back, but I know of a lot more people that want to come back, but they're kind of holding out for more modern life conveniences.
You know, those who have emigrated to outside the country or even inside the country have become accustomed with electricity, although electricity is very little in...
A couple or three hours a day, anyway.
Yeah.
But they want education for their children, they want health care, they want Internet, they want telephones, and there's no reason why we can't provide that.
One of the small projects that we're working on today, in fact, is the concept of the green village.

The concept of the green village is basically coming up with a design of a modern village where we can build houses in a modern way yet maintaining the traditional architectural style while also providing potable water, providing electricity for the compounds, health care, education, all the conveniences that the people are demanding, to facilitate more people coming back.
But the basic idea, we are trying to create the marshes as the economic engine for the economy, for the fishing, for the fowl, for the water buffalo.
And my hope, or our hope that in the future, the marshes can become kind of a center for ecotourism in the area, ecotourism, maybe even historic tourism.
As you know, Ur was on the edges of the marshes, and Ur is where Father Abraham was born, our common ancestor, as it were.
We--I have a lot of faith in the future of the marshes as a place that actually generates income for Iraqis, not just an environmental reserve for birds and animals.
Azzam Alwash, thank you so much for being with us.
Nice to hear an encouraging story from Iraq.
Thank you for giving me the opportunity to ...(unintelligible) your listeners.
Azzam Alwash, director of the Eden Again project.
He joined us by phone from Tokyo.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Now let's go from the entertainment of politics to some holiday entertainment.
NPR TV critic Eric Deggans reviews Bill Murray's ""A Very Murray Christmas.
At times, ""A Very Murray Christmas"" can't decide if it wants to reinvent the style of old school TV Christmas specials or skewer them into oblivion.
Bill Murray begins by referencing two of his best-known roles, the aging movie star from ""Lost In Translation"" and Nick the lounge singer from ""Saturday Night Live.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""A VERY MURRAY CHRISTMAS"")
(As character, singing) I'm going to go disappear.
Wearing an undone bow tie and a lot of melancholy, he stands in a suite at the Carlyle Hotel and delivers a pretty straight version of Christmas blues.
His old SNL pal Paul Shaffer provides the piano.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""A VERY MURRAY CHRISTMAS"")
(As character, singing) Christmas blues.
Before long, we learn why Murray's singing the blues.
He's obligated to host a live Christmas special with his celebrity pals, but a blizzard has shut down New York, and no one has shown up.
His producers, played with frantic perfection by Amy Poehler and Julie White, don't even think Murray's buddy George Clooney will come.
And then the phone rings.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""A VERY MURRAY CHRISTMAS"")
(As character) Please be George.
(As character) Oh, please be George.
(As character) Come on, George.
(As character) Oh, my God.
Is it George Clooney?
(As character) Hey, man.
(As character) Is it George Clooney?
But as NPR's Gwen Thompkins reports, the delegates meeting this weekend face a very difficult challenge - trying to put Somalia on a better path.
A Somali poet once wrote, ""My two hands - left and right - are twins.
One twin gives food to strangers and to guests.
It sustains the weak and guides them.
But the other is a slashing, cutting knife - as sharp to the taste as myrrh, as bitter as the aloe.
He might've been talking about today's crisis in Somalia and the international players meeting in Addis Ababa.
Now, the summit coming of African Union is crucial from the African countries to contribute in peace.
But the donor communities, the European and the United States, has much more critical role to play by reengaging seriously of institution of Somalia.
That's Id Benu Mohamed.
He's a councilor in Somalia's mission to the United Nations.
He will present the pay now or pay more later view of Somalia at the meeting in Addis.
Mohammad says that Uganda, Malawi and Nigeria are among the African states willing to send peacekeepers to help stabilize Somalia.
But African countries need the European Commission and the United States to pay for the mission.
And if need be, he says, the West needs to spend more money than has already been promised.
If not, Mohammad warns that terrorism on the horn of Africa and beyond will be everybody's fault.
The international community immediately engaged the conflict of Liberia, created a government supported by sending in peacekeeping forces led by the African Union.
The international community immediately take the attention of Burundi, supported the peace process, created a government and deployed our force, led by the African Union.
The international community led immediate intervention in Congo, deployed many peacekeeping force, stabilize the situation, ultimately it created a democratic government.
So if the international community has intervened other hot spots as quickly as possible, I don't understand why they are taking so long when it's going to Somalia.
But when it comes to Somalia, the Americans and the Europeans are not always on the same key or the same pitch.
They do start off the same.
U.S.
officials and European diplomats say the first thing they want to see at the African Union meeting is for the full complement of members to commit to an African peacekeeping force in Somalia.
The West wants everyone on stage and singing the same song.
And that goes for Somalia's transitional government, too.
They must demonstrate to the West that they are serious about reconciling with old enemies in the Islamic Courts Union.
We have several times have pleaded to (unintelligible) toward Islam - also Islamic forces to come back home and participate in the reconciliation process.
And we are continuing with that effort.
That's Somali Prime Minister Ali Mohamed Ghedi, talking to diplomats in Nairobi this week.

Somalia's leaders have troubled some members of the European Commission, who worry about the 90 days of martial law there, about the sacking of the parliamentary speaker and about the government's slow pace in making peace with Islamists.
But the U.S., along with Britain, Norway and Denmark, appear less interested in the day to day details of writing Somalia, and more willing to support the transitional government's decisions.
One Somali official described the American approach to Somalia as conflict resolution and the European Commission's approach as conflict management.
But while the diplomats are parsing phrases and attest, Somalis at home have a grocery list of things they'd like to see.
No kidding, it's a grocery list.
Mr.
ALI DOY(ph) (Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in Somalia): Maize, wheat flour, rice, pasta, whatever someone eats in there, and then gluten, and fruits, vegetables and lentils.
It could be kitchen utensils, it could be shelter, set up tents or otherwise blanket Sheets.
Ali Doy is an analyst for the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in Somalia.
He says, these past weeks have been tough on people in southern Somalia, who've have born catastrophic flooding and then fighting.
And in some areas, U.S.
and Ethiopian air strikes.
Access is still severely restricted in areas where people need help the most, which brings us to the words of yet another Somali poet.
Tea and drink of thinned brown honey.
Mutton, spiced and finely sliced.
On such things were my thoughts and my affections set.
But this world provides no lasting satisfaction.
Gwen Thompkins, NPR News, Nairobi.
And you can find complete versions of the poems Gwen was reading from, at NPR.org.
